thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pai), Chiang Mai (Fang, Bo Luang, Doi Chiang Dao, Pha Mon); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok, Ang Thong, Chai Nat, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri, Chanthaburi, Trat (Ko Chang); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Sai Yok, Sangkhla), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Bang Saphan); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Khanthuli), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Ron Phibun), Phatthalung (Thale Sap), Pattani (Khok Pho, Ban Sai Khao).
distribution: India, Ceylon (type), Nepal, Burma, Malesia, Indochina, China, Japan, the Philippines, Micronesia, New Guinea, Australia, Polynesia.
ecology: Riversides, moist grasslands, marshes, rice-fields, open rain forests, at lowlands and up to 1,000 in alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon, Doi Pha Hom Pok, Doi Chiang Dao), Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Khao Kamphaeng).
distribution: W to E Himalayas, Assam, Burma (type), S China, Indochina, Malesia, the Philippines.
ecology: Open pine forests, grassy fields on mountain slopes, grassy vegetation along roads, 1,000–1,700 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Huai Kaeo); EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani (Buntharik); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha).
distribution: Cambodia (type), Laos, Vietnam.
ecology: Rice-fields, open grassy ground, in savannas, 400–1,500 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep), Nakhon Sawan (Takhli); NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon (Wanon Niwat); EASTERN: Si Sa Ket (Kantharalak); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri (Aranyaprathet); SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan (Hua Hin); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Kanchanadit), Songkhla (Ban Pian), Phangnga (Takua Pa), Trang (Khao Chong), Pattani.
distribution: India (type), Ceylon, Malesia, Indochina, S China.
ecology: Open marshy or moist, grassy ground, or sandy soils, near sea up to 600 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – type: Kerr 6600 -BM).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: Open rocky ground with stunted trees in limestone areas, 1,800–2,100 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon), Phrae.
distribution: India, Burma, Laos (Vientiane – type).
ecology: In scrub, evergreen forests and mixed deciduous forests, 200–2,000 m alt. Flowering: March–May.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Pong Yaeng – type: Kerr 3568 -ABD BM K, Doi Chiang Dao); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Tha Khanon).
distribution: Endemic to Thailand.
ecology: Scattered by streams, in evergreen forests, 300–1,500 m alt. Flowering: February–March.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi.
distribution: India (type), Burma, China, Laos.
ecology: In lowland, evergreen forests, 800–900 m alt. Flowering: April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Lampang; NORTH-EASTERN: Nakhon Phanom.
distribution: India (type), Indochina.
ecology: In scrub or bamboo forests, 0–200 m alt. Flowering: April–May.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai, Lampang (Mae Saloi), Phrae (Mae Kham Mi), Sukhothai, Kamphaeng Phet, Nakhon Sawan; EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani (Khemarat); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Kaeng Khoi, Muak Lek), Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); PENINSULAR: Pattani.
distribution: India (type), Burma, Indochina.
ecology: On limestone hills, in mixed deciduous and scrub forests, 50–600 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Chom Thong); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Thung Kamang); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha), Trat (Khao Kuap); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Dong Yai); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Ko Tao, Nong Wai), Phangnga (Than Bok Khorani).
distribution: Indo-Malesia (Bangladesh – type) as far eastwards as the Philippines and Celebes.
ecology: In evergreen forests or scrub, up to 1,300 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Ang Khang, Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Inthanon, Doi Suthep, Fang, Ban Pong), Tak (Pha Wo); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Ban Nam Phrom); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Si Sawat).
distribution: NW India, Bangladesh (type), Himalayas to Assam and Burma.
ecology: Tubers growing between limestone rocks in evergreen forests, sometimes by a streams, also on sandstone, at 350–2,000 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phrae (Huai Mae Khamin); CENTRAL: Lop Buri (Chai Badan), Saraburi (Muak Lek, Sam Lan); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha); SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan (Bang Saphan, Huai Yang, Pran Buri).
distribution: Ceylon, India (type), Vietnam, Malesia (except Malaya, Borneo, Celebes).
ecology: In lowland evergreen or mixed deciduous forests, sometimes on banks of rivers and streams.

thailand: EASTERN: Chaiyaphum; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Krabi, Yala, Pattani.
distribution: From S Africa to Madagascar, Islands of the Pacific Ocean (Tanna Islands – type), SE Asia to Australia and New Zealand.
ecology: Mostly growing along coasts and riverbanks on sandy-clayey soil.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun; CENTRAL: Saraburi; PENINSULAR: Yala.
distribution: Origin unknown, found all over the warmer parts of the world.
ecology: Weedy in open areas.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok).
distribution: As
ecology: As

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon, Doi Chiang Dao), Chiang Rai, Mae Hong Son, Lampang, Lamphun; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Sakon Nakhon, Khon Kaen; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri, Rayong, Trat; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; PENINSULAR: Chumphon.
distribution: From India throughout the Indo-Chinese Peninsula and Indonesia to S China.
ecology: It clearly prefers the monsoon zone and avoids the humid tropics. Highest record from Thailand is 2,100 m alt. It requires high light intensities and is mainly found in open habitats.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; PENINSULAR: Phangnga (Takuapa – type: Larsen et al. 30945 -AAU).
distribution: Endemic, only known from the two collections so far.
ecology: In evergreen forests, also along streams, at low altitudes.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Phitsanulok, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Nong Khai, Sakon Nakhon, Kalasin; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Surin, Ubon Ratchathani; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan.
distribution: From India (type) throughout the Indo-Chinese Peninsula and the Malesian region.
ecology: In open sunny places in forests and very often along streams. In Thailand no records above 550 m alt. but in neighbouring countries up to above 1,000 m.

thailand: EASTERN: Buri Ram; CENTRAL: Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok) (type: Koenig -BM), Ang Thong.
distribution: Widely distributed from tropical Africa to SE Asia, locally abundant, but on the whole rare on the Indo-Chinese Peninsula.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha, Sattahip); SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan (Huai Yang).
distribution: From India, Sri Lanka (type) to Burma, Cambodia and Vietnam.
ecology: Often found in dry sandy areas near the sea. In Thailand also reported from paddy-fields.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (1 collection, Umpa1407 -BK).
distribution: S Brazil (type) and adjacent Argentina and Paraguay. Also collected in Indonesia.
ecology: Xerophytic herb of sunny places. Introduced in Thailand as cover crop in rubber plantation (according to label).

thailand: Common all over the country.
distribution: Cosmopolitan (Sri Lanka – type).
ecology: Weedy on marshy ground, also along waysides, around villages, etc., up to 1,000 m alt. or higher.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son.
distribution: Cosmopolitan (type without locality).
ecology: Weedy, introduced.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Kamphaeng Phet.
distribution: Europe (type) and temperate Asia.
ecology: In damp shady places. In Chiang Mai near the agricultural experimental station and probably introduced with seeds or plants from Europe.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon, Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Suthep).
distribution: From Afghanistan throughout temperate Himalaya (Nepal – type) to SW China, N Vietnam and Japan.
ecology: Open grassy land and light secondary forests at high altitudes.
wfo_full_name: Schizotechium monospermum (Buch.-Ham. ex D.Don) Pusalkar & S.K.Srivast.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao), Chiang Rai; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum.
distribution: E India (Kachin Hills), Burma (Shan Hills – type), China (Yunnan and variants elsewhere).
ecology: Evergreen forests on sandy soil, open pine forests on ridge, mixed deciduous forests on limestone, 400–1,450 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Phuket, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Satun, Songkhla.
distribution: Continental SE Asia from Nepal (India – type) to Yunnan and the Andaman Islands, and throughout Malesia to New Guinea.
ecology: Evergreen forests (e.g. Dipterocarp forests, mixed deciduous forests with much bamboo undergrowth, rain forests on granite) often riverine and mostly in damp shady places but occasionally on rather dry hills, 15–1,650 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon), Chiang Rai (Doi Tung), Tak (Wang Chao), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Ruea), Nong Khai; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok), Nakhon Nayok (Nang Rong); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Sattahip), Trat (K0 Chang, Khlong Son); SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan (Bang Saphan).
distribution: Tropical and subtropical regions of the world (India – type).
ecology: Pond and streamsides, evergreen forests, fields, or as a garden weed, 300–1,450 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao).
distribution: SW China, Vietnam, Burma, Bhutan, Sikkim, Nepal (type), Kashmir, Pakistan.
ecology: Open ground, 1,700–2,100 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai (Doi Langka), Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam), Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao, Chom Thong to Mae Sariang, Om Koi, Mae Sanam, Bo Luang, Pong Pho), Lampang (Mae Mo), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang), Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng – type of var. flotoi ); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Huai Ban Kao, Kriti, Si Sawat).
distribution: Cambodia (type).
ecology: Open places in mixed deciduous dipterocarp and pine forests, in open evergreen forests, limestone crevices on mountain ridges, grassy fields, 450–2,170 m alt.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Nakhon Phanom; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (K0 Chang, Laem Dan); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Si Sawat); PENINSULAR: Phuket (Krasom, Khao Pok), Chumphon (Lang Suan), Phatthalung (Khao Khao), Nakhon Si Thammarat.
distribution: Cultivated throughout E & SE Asia and subspontaneous; Malaysia, the Philippines, Java, Sumatra, New Guinea, SW China, Laos, Vietnam, Burma, India (type), Sri Lanka.
ecology: Cultivated, also in evergreen forests.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao, Khun Khong, Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon, Mae Sanam, Mae Rim, Mae Chaem, Doi Ngao, Doi Pha Hom Pok); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Phu Miang), Loei (Phu Luang), Nong Khai (Chaiyaburi), Nakhon Phanom; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); PENINSULAR: Yala (Tandao).
distribution: SE & E Asia from Sakhalin south through India, China, Japan, Malaysia, the Philippines, Java (type) to New Guinea and Queensland.
ecology: Marshy ground, streamsides, deciduous or evergreen forests, 600–1,700 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – type of Heracleum siamicum , Doi Inthanon, Doi Pha Hom Pok, Doi Suthep), Chiang Rai (Doi Tung), Lampang (Mae Pu); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Huai Ban Kao, Bo Rae – type of H. siamicum var. gracilis ).
distribution: Assam, Burma (type), SW China.
ecology: Mixed and evergreen forests, crevices in limestone rocks, grassy fields, 330–2,250 m alt.

thailand: EASTERN: Chaiyaphum; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Trang (type: Curtis 2914 -BKF).
distribution: Malay Peninsula.
ecology: In evergreen forests, 200–500 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: January–March.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan.
distribution: S China (type), Burma.
ecology: On limestone and granite in deciduous forests, 10–400 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: July–December.

thailand: CENTRAL: Saraburi (Muak Lek – type: Put 3080 -K).
distribution: Endemic to Thailand.
ecology: Flowering: June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Sukhothai, Tak, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; CENTRAL: Chai Nat; SOUTH-EASTERN: Rayong; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Songkhla, Narathiwat.
distribution: China, India (type), Nepal, Ceylon, Malay Peninsula, Indonesia, Brunei, the Philippines, Taiwan, Japan, S Pacific, Australia, Africa.
ecology: In open clearings and seashores, in scrub, deciduous and dry evergreen forests. On sandy soil and limestone rock, from sea level to 800 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: October–December.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Krabi, Trang.
distribution: Malay Peninsula (type), India.
ecology: Scattered in evergreen forests, 50–300 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: January–April.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Nakhon Si Thammarat.
distribution: Malay Peninsula (type).
ecology: On limestone hills in evergreen forests, 20–250 m alt. Flowering: August–September; fruiting: August–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Mae Hong Son, Lamphun, Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi.
distribution: Burma (type), Laos.
ecology: In dry evergreen forests and old clearings, 300–1,300 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: June–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Rim, Ban Kong Mae – type: Bjornland & Schumacher 692 -C).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: In evergreen forests, 700–1,100 m alt. Flowering: February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Lampang; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi; PENINSULAR: Phuket.
distribution: India (type), Burma, China, Vietnam.
ecology: In evergreen forests and shady places in valleys, 100–2,300 m alt. Flowering: February–March.

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP, Pak Thong Chai); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Muang Distr.); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Khao Khieo, Si Racha – type: Collins 460 -K), Chanthaburi (Takhamao Falls, Trat (Ko Chang); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Songkhla (Khao Suan Tun, ex Fletcher).
distribution: Vietnam, West Malaysia, Java, Sumatra.
ecology: In evergreen forests, near streams, 200–800 m alt. Flowering: June; fruiting: November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Lampang, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Nong Khai; EASTERN: Buri Ram, Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima; CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani, Ranong, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Phangnga, Phuket, Trang, Songkhla, Satun, Narathiwat.
distribution: India, Burma, Indochina, West Malaysia, Java (type).
ecology: In evergreen forests, frequent by streams or in damp grassy sites, 30–1,050 m alt. Flowering: October–December; fruiting: April–June.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (Ban Naton); Narathiwat (Su-ngai Kolok, Nikhom Waeng); Songkhla (Ton Nga Chang); Pattani (Khao Kalakhiri – type: Kerr 15016 -K).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: In evergreen forests, 150–400 m alt. Flowering: March.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Mae Nam Noi – type Phengkhlai 286 -BKF, Sai Yok).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: In evergreen forests by streams, 250 m alt. Flowering: November.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Narathiwat (Su-ngai Kolok, Nikhom Waeng).
distribution: West Malaysia (Perak – type).
ecology: In evergreen forests. Flowering: March.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Songkhla (Hat Yai), Narathiwat (Su-ngai Kolok, Nikhom Waeng, To Daeng, To Mo, Ban Wo), Pattani (Khao Kalakhiri), Yala (Than To).
distribution: West Malaysia (type), Singapore, Borneo, Sumatra, Java Celebes.
ecology: In lowland and lower hill evergreen forests, 50–500 m alt. Flowering: February–April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan), Nan (Doi Phu Kha); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Lom Kao); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Khriti, Mueang Cha, Khao Ri Yai).
distribution: China (type), Burma, Vietnam.
ecology: In evergreen forests, 1,000–1,400 m alt. Flowering: March–July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (type: Larsen & Larsen 34357 -AUU).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: Common in clearings, 500–600 m alt. Flowering: September.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khlong Na-kha), Phangnga (Khlong Nang Yon), Nakon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang), Narathiwat (Ban Kumung).
distribution: West Malaysia (type).
ecology: In evergreen forests, at low altitudes (50–100 m). Flowering: April.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Satun (Ko Tarutao).
distribution: Peninsular Malaysia (type).
ecology: In evergreen forests along streams, up to 150 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon – type: Put 3762 -K E ABD; Doi Pha Hom Pok).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: In evergreen forests, 2,100 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Langsuan, Thako – type: Put 1631 -K).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: In lowland evergreen forests.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi, Prachin Buri; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat.
distribution: This is a widespread species found from Assam (type) to S China, and southwards through Indochina to the Malay Peninsula.
ecology: In evergreen forests, 500–2,500 m alt. Flowering: June–July.

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Khao Sok), Phangnga, Nakhon Si Thammarat (Thung Song), Trang (Khao Chong), Songkhla (Na Thawi), Narathiwat (Su-ngai Padi, Tak Bai).
distribution: Cambodia, West Malaysia (type), Java, Sumatra.
ecology: In evergreen forests and thicket, on moist sites and along streams, 100–800 m alt. Flowering: October–November.
scraped_name: Labisia pumila (Blume) Benth. & Hook.f. ex Fern.-Vill.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Nan (Doi Tio); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima.
distribution: India (type), Burma, China.
ecology: Locally common in evergreen forests, 700–2,300 m alt. Flowering: February–March; fruiting: November–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng), Phetchabun (Phu Miang).
distribution: S China (type), Vietnam.
ecology: In evergreen forests, 1,200–1,500 m alt. Flowering: February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; PENINSULAR: Phangnga, Phuket, Krabi.
distribution: China (type), Vietnam.
ecology: In evergreen forests, on sandstone or limestone hills, also found in dry evergreen forests and on ridge area, 250–1,800 m alt. Flowering: December; fruiting: December–February.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Phuket, Satun, Narathiwat (Takbai).
distribution: West Malaysia (type).
ecology: Along rivers in freshwater swamp-forests. Flowering: July.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Phuket, Satun, Narathiwat.
distribution: West Malaysia (type).
ecology: In beach forests, bordering open marshes and paddly fields at low altitudes. Flowering: January.

thailand: [no herbarium specimens have been seen]
distribution: Native in Europe and Asia, introduced and cultivated in many other parts of the world.
ecology: In or alongside running fresh water.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Tham Chiang Dao, Fang)
distribution: Nepal eastwards to China [most provinces except those of the north-east], Japan, Malesia. [Type not indicated].
ecology: Moist ground in forests, dried stream-bed, streamside, 300–400 m alt. (in Fl. Reipubl. Pop. Sin. the altitudinal limit is given as 3,700 m).

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (Tha Samet), Narathiwat (Waeng, Su-ngai Padi).
distribution: From the Nicobar Islands to the Malay Peninsula (type), Sumatra, Java and Borneo.
ecology: Evergreen forests at lower altitudes and swamp forests.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai, Lampang, Phitsanulok, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Udon Thani, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chon Buri, Rayong, Trat; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Phangnga, Phattalung, Satun, Pattani.
distribution: Bangladesh (type: East Bengal), Assam, SE Asia to Australia.
ecology: All forests types as well as open rocky scrubland.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Krabi.
distribution: India, Sri Lanka, Vietnam, China (Hainan), Malaysia, Borneo, Java, Sumatra (type), the Philippines.
ecology: Evergreen forests.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chon Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Satun, Narathiwat.
distribution: India (type), throughout SE Asia, Australia.
ecology: Evergreen forests, often near rivers or streams or in disturbed areas, also on rocky cliffs and scrubby thickets near the sea shore.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Pattani.
distribution: Malay Peninsula, North Borneo, Java (type), Lesser Sunda Islands.
ecology: Evergreen forests.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi.
distribution: The Philippines (type).
ecology: Rain forests.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Narathiwat (Phru To Daeng)
distribution: Vietnam, West coast of the Malay Peninsula (type), S Borneo, Sumatra.
ecology: Swamps behind Mangroves and along rivers.
wfo_full_name: Limahlania crenulata (Maingay ex C.B.Clarke) K.M.Wong & Sugumaran

thailand: NORTHERN: Nan, Lampang; NORTH-EASTERN: Nakhon Phanom; EASTERN: Surin, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani, Trang, Satun, Narathiwat.
distribution: Andaman Islands, N India, S Burma, Vietnam, Malesia (type: Malaysia).
ecology: Evergreen forests, mixed deciduous forests, sandy sea-shores, by roadsides, often planted as an ornamental or for its timber.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong, Surat Thani, Krabi (Nong Plong), Nakhon Si Thammarat, Songkhla, Pattani, Yala, Narathiwat.
distribution: S Burma, Cambodia, Laos, throughout Malesia (except Eastern Java, Madura Islands and the Lesser Sunda Islands; Malaysia – type), Solomon Islands, N Australia.
ecology: Secondary evergreen forests, peat-swamp forests, along roadsides in open areas. On either wet or dry soil.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Phangnga, Satun, Narathiwat.
distribution: West and North Borneo (Sarawak – type), Malay Peninsular, Sumatra.
ecology: Mainly in peat-swamp forests, also in evergreen forests.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Phrae; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; PENINSULAR: Krabi, Narathiwat.
distribution: India, Sri Lanka, Laos, Vietnam, Malay Peninsula, Sabah, Sarawak, China (Hong Kong – type), Sumatra, Java.

ecology: In gallery forests, dry dipterocarp forests, deciduous or evergreen forests, 200–1,000 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai.
distribution: India (type), Nepal.
ecology: In evergreen forests, 1,350–1,525 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Lamphun, Phrae, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Udon Thani, Sakon Nakhon, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima, Buri Ram, Si Sa Ket, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chon Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong, Surat Thani, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Songkhla, Satun.
distribution: China, India, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh (type), Burma, Laos, Vietnam, Cambodia, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines.
ecology: In primary or secondary, evergreen or deciduous forests on a wide variety of soil types or scandent shrub in more open areas to 850 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Pattani.
distribution: Western Indonesia (type from Java), the Philippines, Malay Peninsula.
ecology: In evergreen forests to 200 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Krabi, Trang.
distribution: Java (type), Malay Peninsula, Vietnam, Laos, China, Nepal, Bhutan, India, Burma.
ecology: In evergreen forests to 1,300 m alt.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Udon Thani, Sakon Nakhon, Nakhon Phanom, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima, Buri Ram, Si Sa Ket, Ubon Ratchathani.
distribution: Vietnam (type), Cambodia, Laos.
ecology: In deciduous or partly evergreen forests to 700 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Nan, Lamphun, Lampang, Phrae, Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Sakon Nakhon, Udon Thani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri.
distribution: Burma, China, Laos, Vietnam (type).
ecology: In deciduous or dry evergreen forests.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan.
distribution: Hainan (type), Laos.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai.
distribution: India (type), China, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam.
ecology: In evergreen forests, 1,300–1,560 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai.
distribution: China, Laos (type).
ecology: In evergreen or deciduous forests, 900–950 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Lampang.
distribution: China, Laos, Vietnam, Malay Peninsula (type).
ecology: In evergreen forests, at 1,000 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Kamphaeng Phet, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Surin; CENTRAL: Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Songkhla. Widely cultivated elsewhere.
distribution: Burma, Vietnam, Cambodia, Malaysia, the Philippines. Cultivated elsewhere.
ecology: In forests, scrub or hedgerows to 130 m alt.
scraped_name: Wrightia religiosa (Teijsm. & Binn.) Benth. ex Kurz

thailand: NORTHERN: Nakhon Sawan; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); PENINSULAR: Phatthalung.
distribution: Cambodia (type).
ecology: In mixed forests to 100 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak.
distribution: China, India, Pakistan (type).
ecology: In mixed deciduous forests on limestone, at 500–700 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phuket, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Narathiwat.
distribution: From E Africa to Indonesia (type from Sri Lanka).
ecology: In evergreen or deciduous forests to 700 m alt.

species_scientific_name: Tabernaemontana divaricata (L.) R.Br. ex Roem & Schult.
thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Nan, Lamphun, Lampang, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat?
distribution: N & E India, Sri Lanka (type), Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Burma, Laos, China (Yunnan).
ecology: In forests or scrub to 1,300 m alt.

scraped_name: Tabernaemontana divaricata (L.) R.Br. ex Roem. & Schult.

thailand: PENINSULA: Krabi, Narathiwat.
distribution: Malaysia, Indonesia (type from Java), the Philippines.
ecology: In forests, often on river banks.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Lampang, Phrae; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Krabi.
distribution: Burma (type), Yunnan, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam.
ecology: In forests or open areas, often on river banks, 220–625m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – type: Kerr 6569, holotype -K, isotype -E).
distribution: Endemic to Thailand.
ecology: In scrub jungle, ca 1,800 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon – type: Kerr 6341, holotype -K, isotype -E), Pha Mon spur].
distribution: Endemic to Thailand.
ecology: In evergreen forests, ca 1,500 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon – type: Garrett 403, holotype -K, isotype -E).
distribution: Endemic to Thailand.
ecology: In evergreen forests, 1,600–1,700 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Muang Ha, Doi Suthep; Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri (Sri Racha, Ban Sadet).
distribution: India, Burma (type), China, Cambodia, Malay Peninsula, Vietnam.
ecology: In open forests, on limestone rocks, 420–700 m alt. Flowering: August.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao).
distribution: Burma (type).
ecology: Among limestones or open summit, 1,600–2,100 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai (Muang Tong), Nan; NORTH-EASTERN: Udon Thani, Loei (Chiang Kan).
distribution: India, China, Laos, Vietnam, Indonesia, the Philippines, New Hebrides, Japan. Type collected from the island Vanuatu of Pacific Ocean.
ecology: Wasteland, roadsides, banks of river, 200–400 m alt. Flowering: April–May.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Pilok), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Huai Yang Falls); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani.
distribution: Thailand (new record), Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Java (type).
ecology: In primary rain forests, evergreen forests, depauperate scrubby forests, up to 580 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: mainly October–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phrae (Sung men); PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang NP, Tup Chang, Khiriwong), Trang (Khao Chong), Songkhla (Ton Nga Chang WS); Yala (Banang Sata), Narathiwat (Khao Nikom Waeng, Tan to).
distribution: Sri Lanka, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Indochina, Taiwan, throughout Malesia to the Pacific (Vanuatu – type) up to Tonga and Samoa.
ecology: Primary and secondary evergreen forests, often in open and wet places, such as along rivers and waterfalls, sea level up to 900(–1,700) m alt. Fruits are dispersed by fruit bats and birds, possibly also by water. The trees often carry witches' brooms. Flowering and fruiting throughout the year over its complete range; in Thailand flowering at least in November and May; fruiting in November and June.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Na San), Satun (Khuan Kalong), Songkhla (Boripat Falls Forest Park).
distribution: S Thailand (new record), Malay Peninsula (type), Sumatra (E Coast), Borneo (Sabah).
ecology: Primary evergreen and bamboo forests, soil over a granite bedrock, 50–500 m alt. Flowering: July, September; fruiting: August.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Amphoe Muang, Khao Sabab, Makham, Nong Bon, Phlio Falls, Pong Rat), Trat (Ko Chang, Ko Kut, Takum); PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Bang Son, Khao Muttri, Paknam), Surat Thani (Ko Pa-ngan), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Ban Yan, Khao Chum Tong, Tha Sala Kalo, Thung Song), Songkhla (Hat Yai, Klong Rhang Khao), Pattani (Khao Ken, To Mo), Yala (Banang Sata), Narathiwat (Bacho, Bukematong, Rue So).
distribution: Burma, S Cambodia, S Vietnam, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Borneo (type), the Philippines.
ecology: Rare to very common in flat to mountainous land, dry to periodically flooded. Primary and especially secondary forests, edges of forests, plantations, in secondary regrowths, cultivated land, moss forests, along riverbanks, roads and on the sea shore, on a variety of soils, sea level up to 1,800 m alt. Flowering: August–March (–May); fruiting throughout the year, mainly February–April.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Na Sak), Surat Thani (Jangao), Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang (Khao Ploo), Satun (Sakut), Narathiwat (Sungei Kolok).
distribution: Malay Peninsula (type), Sumatra, Borneo, the southwest Philippines (Balabac Island, Palawan).
ecology: Often common in primary and especially secondary evergreen to deciduous forests, savannas, along roads, rivers, margin of forests, landward edge of mangrove, in peat swamps, sometimes in cultivated fields, on a variety of soils, sea level up to 1,525 m alt. Flowering: mainly (November to) February–April, less so in August and September; fruiting: mainly March–June, less so in September and October.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Khao Kuap); PENINSULAR: Phangnga (Khao Pota Luang Kaeo), Satun (Adang).
distribution: Burma, Cambodia, Vietnam, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Java (type), Borneo, Sulawesi.
ecology: Regularly found in primary and especially in secondary forests, in heath forests, submontane forests, along forests edges, rivers, roads, seashore, in deserted cultivated fields, savannas, on a variety of soils, sea level up to 1,700 m alt. Flowering: September–April; fruiting: December–April.

thailand: CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok) (cultivated).
distribution: Originally known from E Africa, India, and Sri Lanka (type), now introduced pantropically.
ecology: Needs a dry period to grow well and flower. Flowering in at least January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son; SOUTH-EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Chon Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong, Surat Thani, Phuket, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Satun, Narathiwat.
distribution: Bangladesh, India (Assam), Burma, Indochina, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Java (type), Borneo.
ecology: Often common in primary and secondary evergreen forests, but also in peat swamp forests, beach forests, heath forests, or bamboo forests, on plains to slopes and crests, on dry to wet places, on a variety of soils, sea level up to 300( 1,500) m alt. Flowering throughout the year, but mainly in January–April; fruiting: mainly January–August. The fruits are eaten by birds and monkeys.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Narathiwat.
distribution: Malay Peninsula (type), Sumatra, Borneo.
ecology: Primary and secondary evergreen forests on flat land (often peat swamps and periodically inundated areas), slopes, and ridges; on peat, sandy, and clay soils; sea level up to 1,000(–1,600) m alt. Flowering: mainly January–April, also July–October; fruiting: March–April and August–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Nan, Lampang, Tak, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Petchabun, Loei, Udon Thani, Nong Khai; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri, Rayong, Trat; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong, Surat Thani, Pangnga, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Satun.
distribution: From India (type), Burma, SW China throughout SE Asia up to the line Philippines-Borneo-Java.
ecology: Primary and secondary forests, lower montane forests, along the forests edge with savannas, on sandstone and granitic bedrock, (180–)800–2,000 m alt. Flowering and fruiting throughout the year; Thailand: flowering in December–May; fruiting in April–August.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao), Lampang (Ban Pin); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Wang Nam Khiao); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Huai Kha Khaeng), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Bonkrut); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Tung Brong), Chanthaburi (Ban Thakien Thong, Klung); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Bang Bon, Pra Pat Beach), Surat Thani (Bang Bao), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khiriwong), Satun (Ko Tarutao), Songkhla (Boripat Falls NP, Klong Rang Hill), Pattani, Yala, Narathiwat (Khao Tan Yong).
distribution: From NE India (Bay of Bengal) throughout SE Asia up to S China (Hainan), through Malesia (Indonesia, Nusa Kambangan – type) to the Solomon Islands.
ecology: In primary and secondary forests, savannas, on all kinds of soils, 0–1,500 m alt. Flowering: February; fruiting: July–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son.
distribution: Cosmopolitan in the warmer parts of the world, considered neotropical of origin (type from Spain).
ecology: Waste places, old clearings. The one Thai collection originates from an old clearing by hill tribes at Ban Tak Rai, 1,200 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani; CENTRAL: Chai Nat.
distribution: Widely distributed in Europe and Asia (type not designated).
ecology: Forming large populations on sandy flats along the large rivers. Probably spreading in Northern and Central Thailand during the second half of the century.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai (Mae Rim, Bo Kaeo, Bo Luang, Hot, Kongloi – Mae Tho), Chiang Rai (Ban Huai Sak), Lampang (Mt. Samoi, Doi Din Daeng); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP), Loei (Phu Kradueng); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Thung Kamang, Phu Khiao WS), Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Laem, Pakthongchai, Ban Chum Saeng, Huai Talaeng, Khao Yai NP), Buri Ram (Lam Nang), Yasothon (Kemmarat); SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan NP), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Pranburi); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Sam Lan), Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha), Rayong (Sattahip, Thung Brong), Chanthaburi (Makam, Ban Ang), Trat (Khao Saming, Ko Chang); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Ko Samui), Krabi (Ban Ao Luk), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Ban Pa Prek, Nagom, Ronpibun Hill), Trang (Kantang), Satun (Kuan Kalong), Songkhla (Tepha, Khao Kho Hong, Huai Yai, Khao Choomsak, E of Chana, Yo Island, Ban Prakaup), Pattani (Ban Sai Kao), Yala (Bannangsata), Narathiwat (Nikom Waeng, Su-ngai Padi, Bukit, Tomo, Sirinthon Research Centre).
distribution: Bhutan, India (Assam, Sikkim, Meghalaya), Myanmar, S China (Yunnan, Guangxi, Guangdong - type from Guangzhou, Hainan), Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, Malay Peninsula, Indonesia (Sumatra, Java, Sulawesi), Borneo (Sarawak, Sabah), the Philippines, Papua New Guinea, Australia (Northern Territory).
ecology: Dry evergreen forests, dry deciduous forests, dry dipterocarp forests, secondary forests, scrub jungle and thickets. From near sea level to 1,130 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Pang Tong, Tat Noi, Doi Chiang Dao), Phitsanulok (Phu Rom Ro); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng).
distribution: India (Uttah Pradesh, Meghalaya, Manipur), Nepal - type, Myanmar, China (southern provinces), Vietnam, Japan (Ryu-Kyu Islands).
ecology: Evergreen forests, from 800 to 1,800 m alt.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng).
distribution: India (Meghalaya, Assam), China (southern provinces), Taiwan (type), Vietnam.
ecology: Dry evergreen and deciduous forests on sandstone, 500–1,300 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Phota Chong Dong).
distribution: Malay Peninsula, Sumatra.
ecology: Evergreen forests.

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima.
distribution: W Africa, SE Asia to N & E Australia (type).
ecology: In pools and ditches, and along riverbanks.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Si Sawat); CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok).
distribution: India (type), Vietnam, Malay, Sumatra, the Philippines.
ecology: Fresh water aquatic of streams, ponds, rivers, rice paddies, from near sea level to 500 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Satun.
distribution: Indian Ocean to Australia, Marianne Islands (type).
ecology: In sheltered localities on sandy or muddy substrates to depths of about 2 meters.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nan; PENINSULAR: Trang, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Phatthalung.
distribution: India to Malesia (type) and E Asia.
ecology: Fresh water ponds and shallow rivers.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, Pathum Thani, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok), Samut Prakan; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri; Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Songkhla.
distribution: Worldwide (except zones with severe frosts).
ecology: Rather eutrophic, still water.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai, Phitsanulok; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima.
distribution: India (type), Burma, China, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Malay Peninsula, Malesia.
ecology: Near streams in evergreen forests, 600–800 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: November–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon).
distribution: S China, India (type), Nepal, Bhutan, Burma, Vietnam, Malay Peninsula, Indonesia.
ecology: In hill evergreen forests, 1,600–2,200 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: January–June.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Khao Khiao); PENINSULAR: Krabi (Phanom Bencha).
distribution: S China (type), Indochina, Malesia.
ecology: In evergreen forests, 600–1,000 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: December–March.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Trang (only collection: Geesink 7281).
distribution: Malay Peninsula, Riouw Archipelago, Sumatra (type), Bangka Islands, Borneo, New Guinea.
ecology: In evergreen rain forests often beside streams on granitic rock, in Thailand below 200 m alt.

thailand: EASTERN: Si Sa Ket, Ubon Rachathani; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Ko Chang, Klawng Kloi, 50 m – type of Melastoma acutisepalum : Kerr 9244 -BK).
distribution: Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam (type).
ecology: On rocky ground or cliffs in mixed evergreen and deciduous forests, also in open thickets on sandy soil or in savannas, up to 600 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat.
distribution: Borneo, Sulawesi.
ecology: In evergreen forests at 1,700 m alt.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi.
distribution: From India (syntypes) across SE Asia and Malesia to New Guinea, the Philippines, New Hebrides and N Australia.
ecology: In mixed deciduous and hill evergreen forests.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum.
distribution: Nepal (type), Bhutan, India, S China, Burma, Laos, Vietnam, Malay Peninsula.
ecology: Found on rocky ground or in heavy soils or bogs, apparently occasionally cultivated as an ornamental, at 300–1,400 m alt.

species_scientific_name: Osbeckia stellata Buch.-Ham. ex Ker Gawl.
thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep – type of Osbeckia racemosa : Kerr 836 -K, Payap/Paya, Doi Angka – type of O. garrettii : Garrett 51 -BKF K, Doi Suthep – type of O. paludosa : Kerr 2740 -BK K, Doi Suthep, 1600 m – type of O. pulchra : Kerr s.n. -K; Doi Suthep – type of var. rubra : Kerr s.n. -BK), Chiang Rai, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Sakhon Nakhon, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Surin; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri; PENINSULAR: Satun.
distribution: Nepal (lectotype), Bhutan, India, Burma, S China, Taiwan, Indochina, naturalized on Mauritius.
ecology: Common in open areas but also found in evergreen or deciduous forests, often on marshy ground, up to 2,000 m alt.
specific_name: Osbeckia stellata Buch.-Ham. ex Ker Gawl.
specific_name_clean: osbeckia stellata buch.-ham. ex ker gawl.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun.
distribution: Nepal (type), China, Taiwan and the Malayan Archipelago.
ecology: Marsh on summit, 1,400–2,450 m alt.

thailand: CENTRAL: Saraburi (Sam Lan); Nakhon Nayok (Sarika Falls – type: Larsen et al. 3402 -AAU BKF C).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: Along streams, at altitudes below 400 m.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (Phu Mieng – type: Larsen et al. 1105 -AAU BKF C).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: Growing on rocks by a stream in evergreen forests. Only known from the type, which was collected at 700 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang – type of Blastus stellulatus : Smith 721 -BK K), Trang.
distribution: Indochina, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Borneo (type), Celebes.
ecology: Common in the undergrowth of evergreen forests, 400–1,600 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Chumphon (La-un – type of Phaulanthus pedunculatus : Kerr 16491 -BM BK K), Ranong (Larsen et al. 43107), Surat Thani, Phangnga (Kapong – type of P. nervosus : Kerr 17127 -BM BK K), Songkhla (Klawng Yai – type of P. brevidens : Kerr 15888 -BK BM K).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: Evergreen forests.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Satun, Songkhla, Yala, Narathiwat.
distribution: In the New World from Mexico to Bolivia, an invasive pest, called Koster's Curse, in much of the paleotropics and especially in Hawaii.
ecology: Disturbed sites, from sea level to 150 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga (Kapong, Takuapa – type of Marumia impressa : Kerr 17110 -BK K), Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Phatthalung, Trang, Satun, Songkhla, Yala (Bannang Sata – type of M. dimorpha : Kerr 7283 -BK K), Narathiwat.
distribution: Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Borneo (Bandjermasin: Gunong Sakoembang – type of
ecology: Along margins of evergreen primary or secondary forests, from sea level to 1,000 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: year-round.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Narathiwat (Su-ngai Padi – type of var. esetosa : Bourke s.n. -BK K).
distribution: Malay Peninsula (Malacca – type of
ecology: Along margins of primary or old secondary forests at low altitudes.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Songkhla, Yala, Narathiwat.
distribution: Malay Peninsula (Lingga Archipelago), Sumatra (types of
ecology: forests margins and gaps at low altitudes.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat, Phatthalung, Narathiwat.
distribution: Indochina, Malay Peninsula (Kedah, Penang, Perak, Selangor, Johore), Sumatra (types of
ecology: In evergreen forests or in disturbed places, such as forests margins and gaps, low altitudes up to 600 m.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat; PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Khao Nam Sao – type of var. tetramera : Kerr 12054 -BK K), Ranong (Khao Patwa Chondong, 12 km N of Kapoe, 900 m – type of Medinilla elliptica : Kerr 16779 -BK K), Phangnga, Phatthalung, Trang.
distribution: Sumatra (type).
ecology: Evergreen forests at 800–900 m alt.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Smitinand 1928, Sorensen 6269); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Khao Nawng, 800 m – type of Medinilla ferrata : Kerr 13253 -BK K, see type photo in Maxwell 1978, pl. 2).
distribution: Sumatra, Java (type of
ecology: Evergreen lower montane forests at 700–1,300 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang: Smitinand 867).
distribution: Malay Peninsula [Pahang, Perak (syntypes of
ecology: In evergreen forests or on exposed rocks, lowland to 2,000 m alt. (outside Thailand).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai, Lampang, Sukhothai, Phitsanulok, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Udon Thani, Nong Khai, Maha Sarakham; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima, Surin, Si Sa Ket, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri, Trat; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phatthalung, Satun, Songkhla.
distribution: Bangladesh, Burma, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, Sumatra (type), Malay Peninsula.
ecology: Locally frequent in evergreen or deciduous forests, especially on stream-sides and marshes, 0–400 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Tak (Wang Chao – type of Polygala ardisioides Craib: Kerr 4571 -K); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok).

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Phangnga, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Satun, Songkhla.

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Sai Yok).

thailand: PENINSULAR: Ranong, Trang.

thailand: CENTRAL: Samut Prakan; SOUTH-EASTERN: Rayong, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Krabi, Trang, Satun, Narathiwat.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Nakhon Phanom; EASTERN: Mukdahan; CENTRAL: Saraburi.

distribution: Tropical and subtropical Asia (from Nepal and N India to S China, Vietnam, Cambodia, Malesia, Indonesia, the Philippines and Papua New Guinea).

thailand: PENINSULAR: Krabi (Khao Phra-Bang), Songkhla (Klong Hoi Kong).

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Songkhla, Pattani, Narathiwat.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng).

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam).
distribution: Himalaya (Nepal – type) to Laos and China.
ecology: In dipterocarp and pine forests, 600 m alt.

thailand: Usually cultivated, probable collections of wild origin in PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Pathio), Satun (Adang Island), Songkhla.
distribution: Pantropical garden ornamental and weed, originating from southern U.S.A., Mexico (type) and C America.
ecology: Garden escape around habitations, as a weed in open places and on waste ground, collected on limestone, 10–50 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: probably the whole year through.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Mae Sam Lap along the Salawin River).
distribution: Burma (type).
ecology: Temporarily inundated river floodplain, between basalt rocks, 150 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Klang Falls, Mae Soi, Muang Hot near Doi Noi); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao).
distribution: Sri Lanka, India (‘India orientalis’ – type), Burma.
ecology: In dry deciduous dipterocarp forests, on sunny dry places; on rocks in loamy soil and near streams, on granite; 200–500 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: June, November–January.

thailand: Common in cultivation, but rarely collected.
distribution: The most widespread species of the genus, from the USA (Florida) to northern S America and most of the Antilles. Eight subspecies distinguished, most of them local endemics on the Antilles.
ecology: In the Americas, growing in a wide range of habitats, in coastal scrub, arid thorn forests, dry deciduous forests, or in exposed, rocky sites of more humid environments, and more frequent on limestone.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Songkhla (Hat Yai Na Thawi), Narathiwat (Su-ngai Kolok).
distribution: Native to C & S America (from Mexico to Argentina, type from French Guiana and cultivated in Paris); introduced and naturalizing in W and E Africa, Sri Lanka, Malesia from the Malay Peninsula to Papua New Guinea.
ecology: Weed on waste places, old plantations, roadsides, sea level to ca 60 m (outside Thailand to 600 m). Flowering and fruiting: August, October, December.

thailand: CENTRAL: Lop Buri (Khao Thungna); SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo (Roi Pi Botanical Garden), Prachin Buri (Kabinburi – type: Ogiso & Phromdej 229, holotype -TI), Chachoengsao, Chon Buri (Chantaten Falls, Khao Khiao). Also cultivated, e.g. in Chiang Mai, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok), Saraburi.
distribution: Endemic? To be expected in Cambodia.
ecology: In rock crevices and rocky deciduous forests, mixed bamboo forests, dry evergreen forests, on roadside, 30–500 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: December–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Phayao, Nan, Lamphun, Lampang, Phrae, Tak, Sukhothai, Phitsanulok, Kamphaeng Phet, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Nong Khai, Sakon Nakhon, Nakhon Phanom, Mukdahan; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo, Chanthaburi.
distribution: India (type from Calcutta), Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Burma, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam.
ecology: In mixed and dry deciduous forests, mixed evergreen/deciduous forests, dipterocarp-oak forests, disturbed hill and dry evergreen forests, Imperata or bamboo vegetation, fire-prone areas, secondary growths, road sides and old clearings, rocky slopes, dry or at streams; over limestone, sandstone, basalt or granite; 10–950 m alt. Flowering: November March. (May); fruiting: January–April. The flowers are scented or with foetid odor.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Trang, Songkhla, Yala, Narathiwat.
distribution: Malay Peninsula (type), Sumatra, Borneo.
ecology: Lowland forests.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Pattani, Narathiwat.
distribution: Malay Peninsula (type), Sumatra, Borneo.
ecology: Lowland peat swamp forests often as monospecific regrowths.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Provincial areas?.
distribution: Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Bangka (type), Borneo.
ecology: Widespread and common on both clay and sandy soils, common colonist of wet gullies along roadsides, alluvial forests areas, and the margins of degraded swamp forests, only known below 600–700 m alt.

thailand: Widespread.
distribution: India, Nepal, Bhutan, Sri Lanka, China, Laos, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Java (type).
ecology: Common in secondary forests, sea level to 1,200 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Phrae.
distribution: India (type), Sri Lanka.
ecology: Secondary forests.

thailand: See under varieties.
distribution: India to China, Japan, all Malesia (Maluku – type), Queensland and Melanesia.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH EASTERN: Rayong, Chanthaburi, Trat.
distribution: Lower Burma, India, Vietnam, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra (type), Borneo.
ecology: Sometimes forming thickets. In continental Asia very patchy.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat.
distribution: Sumatra, Malay Peninsula (except northeast, Singapore – type).
ecology: Open places, often gregarious, sometimes on exposed subsoil, lowlands to 1,000 m alt.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan (Huai Thap Sakae); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Kraburi), Surat Thani (Khao Tum, Khlong Saeng, Wang Sai), Phangnga (Bangto), Krabi (Nai Sa), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Chong, Krung Ching Falls, Ron Phi Bun), Trang (Khao Chang), Pattani (To Mo), Narathiwat (Waeng).
distribution: Burma, Laos, Vietnam, throughout Malesia (Java – type) up to the Solomon Islands.
ecology: By streams in evergreen forests, limestone bedrock, 40–300 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Phayao, Lampang, Phrae, Uttaradit, Sukhothai, Nakhon Sawan; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chon Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Phuket, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Phatthalung, Trang, Satun, Songkhla, Pattani, Yala, Narathiwat.
distribution: Burma, Andaman Islands, Indochina, throughout Malesia to New Guinea.
ecology: In a large variety of vegetations, varying from deciduous (mixed) forests to evergreen forests, bamboo forests, mixed oak forests, often along water or in rocky areas, also in very disturbed places, like thickets, edges of forests, fields; soil: shale, limestone or granite bedrock; 0–800 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Ko Pang, Pa To), Ranong (Khao Nam Ron, Kraburi, Phato), Krabi (Ao Luk, Khao Panom), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang), Phatthalung (Khao Pu-Khao Ya), Trang (Khao Chong, Qutong), Satun (Nam Rah), Songkhla (Ko Hong), Pattani (Banang Sta), Yala (Kue Long).
distribution: Lower Burma, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Java (type).
ecology: From cleared forests, open thickets to secondary forests, to dry to wet evergreen forests, often along forests margin or stream; soil: limestone, granitic bedrock; 0–450 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Lampang, Phrae, Tak, Sukhothai, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Nong Khai, Sakon Nakhon, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo, Chon Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Pattani, Narathiwat.
distribution: Burma, S China, Taiwan, Indochina, throughout Malesia (Java – type) to Australia (Queensland).
ecology: Common pioneer in very secondary habitats like grassy clearings in montane mixed oak forests, dipterocarp forests, mixed deciduous forests; also along peat swamp margins, and along road sides and forests edges; soil: sandstone and granite bedrock; 0–1,500 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Pata), Ranong (Pak Chan, Phapat beach), Surat Thani (Khao Habsib), Phuket (Khao Pra Thaeo), Krabi (Nong Li), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Chawang, Khao Luang, Kung Ching Falls), Trang (Khao Chong), Songkhla (Ton Nga Chang, Kho Hong, Rattapum), Yala (Banang Sata, Klong Mu Bo, Than To), Narathiwat (Bala Hala, Waeng).
distribution: Malay Peninsula, Sumatra (Bangka Island – type), Borneo.
ecology: Usually in disturbed habitats in evergreen forests, along roads, edges of forests, open thickets, along rivers, limestone bedrock, 0–500 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai (Phayapri village [Akha tribe]).
distribution: Sri Lanka, India, Bangladesh, China (Yunnan). Probably also present in Burma.
ecology: Pioneer species found in disturbed evergreen forests, sometimes mixed with deciduous elements, along roadsides, in thickets in cultivated areas, garden boundaries and secondary forests, bedrock granite, 0–1,600 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo), Satun (Ko Kaeo, Klong Ton), Pattani (Khao Kalakiri).
distribution: Sumatra (type), Borneo.

wfo_full_name: Hancea stipularis (Airy Shaw) S.E.C.Sierra, Kulju & Welzen

thailand: PENINSULAR: Yala (Khlong Mu Bo, Than To), Narathiwat (Waeng).

thailand: PENINSULAR: Narathiwat (Bala-Hala).

ecology: In understorey of evergreen and (late) secondary forests, sometimes in young secondary forests or scrubs, usually along water in mainly well drained terrain; soils very variable, from clay, sand, loam, sandstone, limestone, alluvial; up to 1,700 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Songkhla (Boriphat Falls), Narathiwat (Bacho).
distribution: Indochina, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Java (type).
ecology: Mainly in shaded places in primary evergreen forests, also along streams, sea shore and in waste places, always limestone bedrock, 0–250 m alt.

distribution: India (type?), Burma, Andaman Islands, Central Java (Indonesia). The plant has probably been accidentally introduced in Java, because it is only known from an area with a sugar cane factory.

ecology: Wild and cultivated on a variety of substrates and in many different kinds of vegetation, including plantations. Young plants are pioneers in the Australian vineforests, 0–1,000 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Pattani (Sai Khao Falls), Yala (Nikhom Kue Long), Narathiwat (Bacho).

thailand: Common all over the country.
distribution: From India, Nepal, Bhutan, Burma and S China t Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam, throughout Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines to N Australia and New Guinea. (“Ind. Orient.”, probably Phuket, Thailand – type: König -C).
ecology: Occurring in a variety of biotopes from peat swamp forests in the south at sea level to hill evergreen forests in the north, e.g. on Doi Inthanon, up to 1,400 m alt. Also common in the lowland deciduous forests in the central and north. It is found on limestone as well as on granitic rocks, in sunny places as well as in shade, preferable on humid ground.

ecology: Tropical evergreen rain forests, 900–1,500 m alt. Flowering and fruiting; February–March.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Songkhla.
distribution: Malaysia (type).
ecology: Tropical evergreen rain forests, often near streams, on granite bedrock, up to 200 m alt. Flowering and fruiting; July–August.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Phangnga, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Pattani.
distribution: Malaysia (type).
ecology: Tropical evergreen rain forests, 650–1,000 m alt. Flowering: November; fruiting: April–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Nakhon Phanom; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Trang, Satun, Pattani, Yala, Narathiwat.
distribution: Burma (type), Malaysia.
ecology: Scrub and secondary forests, evergreen rain forests, on limestone bedrock, often near streams, 10–300 m (most commonly 50–100 m). Flowering: January–December (most commonly July–September); fruiting: January–September (most commonly March–June).

thailand: PENINSULAR: Narathiwat.
distribution: Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia (type).
ecology: Peat swamp forests, lowland tropical evergreen rain forests.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Songkhla, Pattani, Yala, Narathiwat.
distribution: Malaysia, Indonesia (type), Brunei.
ecology: Swamp forests, tropical evergreen rain forests, 50–900 m alt. Flowering: April–November (most commonly April–September); fruiting: July–December (most commonly July–September).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai.
distribution: China, Burma (type), India, Laos, Vietnam.
ecology: Lower montane rain forests, 1,400–2,400 m alt. Flowering and fruiting; October–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Nakhon Phanom; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima.
distribution: Vietnam (type).
ecology: Tropical evergreen rain forests, often near streams, 100–1,500 m (most commonly 1,200 m). Flowering: February–December (most commonly November December); fruiting: February–December (most commonly February–April).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi.
distribution: China (type), Burma.
ecology: Lower montane rain forests, evergreen forests on granite bedrock, 1,100–2,500 m (most commonly 1,500–2,000 m). Flowering and fruiting, usually at the same time. Flowering: January–March and fruiting: January–December (most commonly January–March).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima.
distribution: Vietnam (type).
ecology: Lower montane pine-oak forests, tropical evergreen rain forests, pine deciduous dipterocarp forests, limestone hill, often near streams, 800–2,500 m (most commonly 800–1,200 m). Flowering: January–December (most commonly January–May); fruiting: January–December (most commonly June–September), usually flowering and fruiting at the same time.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Phangnga.
distribution: Laos, Vietnam, China, Korea, Japan (type).
ecology: Deciduous dipterocarp forests, dry evergreen forests, tropical evergreen rain forests, sandy soils or granite bedrock, often near streams, 50–900 m (most commonly 500–900 m). Flowering: February–December (most commonly October–December); fruiting: March–December (most commonly August–October).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Lamphun, Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei.
distribution: India, Burma (type), Laos.
ecology: Tropical evergreen rain forests, open sandy soils, open gallery forests, sandstone or granite bedrock, 500–1,750 m (most commonly 900–1,300 m). Flowering: February–December (most commonly November–December); fruiting: February–August (most commonly June–August).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (only known from Doi Chiang Dao).
distribution: China (Yunnan – type).
ecology: Exposed on limestone bed-rock, 1,750–2,400 m alt. Flowering: September–November; fruiting: October–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep NP, Doi Chiang Dao), Nan (Doi Phu Kha), Lampang (Chae Son NP), Phitsanulok (Phu Miang); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan (Kaeng Krachan NP); CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH EASTERN: Rayong (Khao Cha Mao NP), Sa Kaeo.
distribution: NE India, Bangladesh (lectotype), Bhutan, Myanmar, S China (Yunnan, Hainan), Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam, through Langkawi I., N Sumatra, the Philippines, east to NE Australia (Queensland) and the Pacific (Solomon Islands, east to Fiji); not in C & S Sumatra, Java, Borneo.
ecology: Shaded and open places in primary evergreen montane forests and evergreen seasonal forests along streams, clayey soils on limestone and granite bedrock, 200–1,000 m alt. Flowering: October–November; fruiting: January.

thailand: Widely distributed.
distribution: Possibly also Cambodia.
ecology: Open forests and scrub, and over rocks; common on limestone, also on granite; lowland up to 1,800 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: mainly in the rainy season.
wfo_full_name: Hemsleya cirromitrata (W.J.de Wilde & Duyfjes) H.Schaef. & S.S.Renner

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao), Tak; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Erawan Falls), Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan NP); PENINSULAR: Phuket, Krabi, Songkhla, Narathiwat (Waeng).
distribution: Widespread, from NE India and S China, through Indochina (Vietnam – type) and Malesia to N Australia; not in India, Sri Lanka, Java, and the Pacific, rare in Sumatra.
ecology: forests and (degraded) forests edges on a wide range of land forms and soils, usually in the lowlands to 1,000 m alt.

thailand: Cultivated locally in the mountains.
distribution: Originally wild and cultivated in C America, now widely cultivated (usually over trellis) in the tropics and subtropics all over the world.

thailand: Widely cultivated.
distribution: Originally in S Asia (India), at present widely cultivated. (Type not yet indicated).

distribution: Widespread, from S China through Indochina into W Malesia (Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Borneo, Java).
ecology: Open or disturbed places in evergreen forests, hill dipterocarp forests on acid rock, forests edges, scrub, 0–1,500 m alt. Flowering: April; fruiting: May, September, November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nan (Doi Phu Kha NP, known from 2 collections).
distribution: S Yunnan, N Vietnam (type), Laos.
ecology: Hill evergreen forests, by streams, 1,100–1,500 m alt.

thailand: Known from all provinces.
distribution: Widespread: India, Sri Lanka, S China, Myanmar, Indochina (Annam – type), south-east to the Philippines and Lesser Sunda Islands east to Sumbawa, not known from Sumatra and Borneo.
ecology: Roadsides, disturbed places, 0–1,000 m alt. Flowering and fruiting throughout the year.

thailand: Known from all provinces.
distribution: Widespread: north-eastern part of India, China, through Indochina (type), east to Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo, Java, the Philippines, Celebes, Lesser Sunda Islands east to Flores.
ecology: forests edges, clearings, scrub, in hedges and in open fields, 0–1,000 m alt. Flowering and fruiting throughout the year.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Khao Khiao); PENINSULAR: Pattani, Satun.
distribution: W Malesia: Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore (type), Sumatra, Java, Borneo (Sarawak).
ecology: Open areas, forests edges, in evergreen forests, 200–900 m alt. Flowering: April and June; fruiting: March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon NP, Doi Suthep-Pui NP, Doi Luang NP); Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP); Lampang (en route from Pang La to Huai Tak); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Samhaek); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Huai Ban Kao).
distribution: Burma (type).
ecology: Mixed deciduous forests, evergreen seasonal forests and scrub, bamboo thickets, stream-sides, on limestone and phylletic bedrock, at 350–2,000 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: August–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon NP, Mae Sa, Doi Chiang Dao WS); Chiang Rai (Doi Tung); Phrae (Mae Yom NP); Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen (Phu Khiao WS); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Khaobuing); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Khao Khiao).
distribution: N India, east to China, through Malesia (Java – type, east to Borneo and the Philippines); not known from Celebes, Lesser Sunda Islands, and New Guinea.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao WS, Doi Inthanon NP), Nan, Lampang (Chae Son NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen (Doi Phanok Khao); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Tham Tan Lot NP); CENTRAL: Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, Saraburi (Phu Khae); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Ang Phak Nam).
distribution: Widespread: Africa (type), SW & SE Asia, including Yemen, Pakistan, India, Sri Lanka, north-east and east to China, Ryukyus, Indochina, through Malesia to New Guinea and Australia.
ecology: Periodically dry places in a large variety of (degraded) scrub-land, savanna, and (seasonal) forests (edges); for Thailand recorded from shale bedrock; for Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam (Keraudren l.c.) recorded from basaltic rock; 1–1,300 m alt. Flowering and fruiting throughout the year.

species_scientific_name: Neoachmandra hermaphrodita (W.J.de Wilde & Duyfjes) W.J.de Wilde & Duyfjes
thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan NP – type: de Wilde & Duyfjes 22289, holotype -BKF, isotype -L), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Kui Buri NP).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: Roadsides in evergreen (secondary) forests, 100–600 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: August–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Mae Sariang), Chiang Mai (Huai Din Dam, Doi Chiang Dao, Mae Pau, Doi Suthep NP, Doi Inthanon NP, Op Luang NP, Doi Luang NP, Ban Pong, Doi Muang Awn, Mae Soi Valley), Chiang Rai (Doi Tung), Nan, Lampang (Chae Son NP, Huai Thak, Doi Pang La), Tak, Nakhon Sawan; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Sai Yok), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Thap Sakae); CENTRAL: Lop Buri, Saraburi (Sam Lan).
distribution: China (Yunnan), E Myanmar (type).
ecology: (Open deciduous) forests; gullies, damp shaded sites; on granitic, shale, or limestone bedrock; 100–1,500 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: (June) July–November.

species_scientific_name: Neoachmandra sphaerosperma (W.J.de Wilde & Duyfjes) W.J.de Wilde & Duyfjes
thailand: CENTRAL: Lop Buri (Bencha Khiri Temple – type: Pooma, de Wilde, Duyfjes, Chamchumroon & Phattarahirankanok 3043, holotype -BKF, isotpye L), Saraburi (Tap Kwang).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: Trailing in light shade over eroded limestone rock, 100–350 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: August–October. The fruits are bright red when ripe and juicy with big creamy-white seeds, which are carried away into crevices by ants, obviously facilitating local dispersal.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nakhon Sawan (type: Phonsena, de Wilde & Duyfjes 4015, holotype -L, isotype -BKF); SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan NP).

ecology: In blackish soil in depression of limestone, shaded, at ca 100 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: September.

ecology: On limestone rock, 50–400 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: June–December.

ecology: In and along waste gardens, forests edges, shaded roadsides, 0–500(–1,400) m alt. Flowering and fruiting: mainly July–December.
wfo_full_name: Zehneria odorata (Hook.f. & Thomson ex C.B.Clarke) M.D.Dwivedi, A.K.Pandey & H.Schaef.

ecology: Ground layer of hill evergreen forests dominated by

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pang Tong), Chiang Mai (Pong Dueat Nature Park, Mae Taeng, Omkoi, Huai Maenam Noi), Nan (Nam Ken), Lamphun (Mae Tha), Lampang (Chae Son, Maharat – syntypes of Gymnosporia stylosa var. rectispinosa ): Kerr 3100, Kerr 4764; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Erawan NP, Sai Yok, Sisawat, Tham Pha), Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan NP); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Khao Nong), Krabi (Khao Phanom Bencha).
distribution: Malaysia (type).
ecology: Evergreen and deciduous forests, sometimes found on limestone, from near sea level to 1,300 m alt. Flowering: February, April, May, July, December; fruiting: January–March, July, October–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Mae Ping Rapids – syntypes: Kerr 3047, Kerr 3047a).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: On river bank, 150–200 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: December.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Ratchaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan (Sam Roi Yot); CENTRAL: Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok), Samut Sakhon (Ban Khlong Su); SOUTH EASTERN: Chon Buri (near Si Racha).
distribution: Laos, Vietnam (type), Malaysia, Indonesia.
ecology: In marsh or dry thicket, along the beaches or river, limestone range near sea, at low altitudes. Flowering: January, July; fruiting: February, May, December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon, Doi Khun Huai Pong); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Ubon Ratchathani (Chong Mek); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Sangkhla Buri; Sesawo); SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Ko Chang; Ko Kut ); PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Ban Kraye, Tasan), Ranong (Kapoe, Khlong Wa), Surat Thani (Ban Ta Khun), Phangnga (Khao Katakwam, Khao Phra Mi), Phuket (Kamala), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Ron Phi Pun), Trang (Yan Ta Khao), Songkhla (Ban Prakop), Pattani (Khao Kala Khiri), Yala (Betong).
distribution: India (type), Myanmar, S China (Yunnan), Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, Peninsular Malaysia (Penang).
ecology: Evergreen and deciduous forests, exposed ridge with dense shrubby vegetation mostly less than 2 m high, from sea level to 1,800 m alt. Flowering: January–May, July, August, October–December; fruiting: April, May, August, October, December.

thailand: NORTHERN:Nan (Doi Tieo, Sapan Falls); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei (Phu Thong); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Khao Yai), Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan NP); SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Khao Kop); PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Bang Son, Langsuan), Surat Thani (Ban Yong Yao, Khiansa), Phangnga, Krabi (Khao Phanom Bencha NP), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang, Khao Ron), Phatthalung (Si Ban Phot), Trang (Khao Chong), Satun (Ko Adang, La Ngu), Songkhla (Khao Nam Khang, Nathawi, Ton Plieo Falls), Narathiwat (Waeng).
distribution: India (Andaman Islands – type, Nicobars), Myanmar (Tenasserim), Laos, Vietnam, Malay Peninsula (also Penang Island), Indonesia, the Philippines.
ecology: Evergreen forests, 20–1,500 m alt. Flowering: January–March, May, June; fruiting: March, May–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao).
distribution: Pakistan, India, Nepal (type), Bhutan, Myanmar, China, Japan.
ecology: In sunny place with limestone.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Ban Nam Phrom); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (between Huai Ban Kao and Kriti); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Muak Lek), Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai NP).
distribution: Pakistan, India, Myanmar, China (type), Vietnam, the Philippines, Indonesia, also widely cultivated.
ecology: Evergreen forests, forests by river bank, 100–800(–2600) m alt. Flowering: April, May, July; fruiting: May, July, December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Klang), Lampang (Maharat); NORTH EASTERN: Phetchabun; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Nam Phrom); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Than: (Ban Rai), Kanchanaburi (Sangkhla Buri); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri (Krabin), Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao); PENINSULAR: Phangnga.
distribution: Myanmar (type), China, Cambodia, Vietnam.
ecology: In evergreen, also mixed forests, sometimes found on limestones, from lowland to 900 m alt. Flowering: February; fruiting: February–May, December.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Phuket (Ko Kho Kao), Songkhla (Nathawi), Narathiwat (Pa Wai).

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha).

ecology: Lowland evergreen forests, sometimes to ca 700 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam, Mae Sariang), Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Sang Liang; Doi Suthep – type of Leea pallida Craib: Kerr 3390, holotype -K; Fang Hot Spring NP, Wang Tao), Chiang Rai (Ban Mai Phatthana), Nan (Doi Phu Kha NP), Tak (Mu Ki Hao village), Kamphaeng Phet (Mae Klong – type of L. parallela Wall. ex M.A.Lawson var. puberula Craib: Kerr 6135, holotype -K); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Khao Laem Dam NP, Sai Yok NP, Sri Sawat); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Kaeng Khoi, Sam Lan Forest); PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Kuring).
distribution: India (type), Bhutan, Nepal, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Cambodia, Laos.
ecology: Shady to open places in deciduous or dry evergreen forests, disturbed mixed deciduous (teak) forests, fire damaged secondary forests with bamboo, in marshy places bordering rice fields, along moist roadsides, grassy slopes; soil: once recorded from sand, several times limestone and as bedrock: granite and shales, 100–950 m alt. Flowering: July–November; fruiting: September, November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Mae Sariang), Chiang Mai (Ban Ta Fang, Bo Luang, Doi Chang, Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Saket, Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon NP, Kongloi, Mae Klang Falls, Omkoi), Chiang Rai (Ban Mai Phatthana, Doi Tung, Khunchae NP), Nan (Doi Cham On), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang (Chae Son NP), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Ban Paek), Loei (Nam Nao NP, Phu Kradueng); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Ban Hang); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Huai Bankao, Ku Chae, Sri Sawat, Thong Pha Phum, Thung Phra Russi); PENINSULAR: Phangnga (Similan NP).
distribution: India, Bhutan, Nepal, Bangladesh, Myanmar, China (Yunnan), Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam.
ecology: In (the more) open places in dry evergreen dipterocarp forests, fire-damaged degraded deciduous dipterocarp-oak hardwood forests, open pine forests, grassy dipterocarp pine forests, open thickets, grass fields, gallery forests, rocky ridges, in marshy areas. Bedrock: granite and limestone, 100–1,450 m alt. Flowering: May–July, September; fruiting: June–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Lan Sang NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Nong Khai (Ban Non Yang); EASTERN: Buri Ram, Surin (Murnsriyai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Ban Erawan); CENTRAL: Nakhon Pathom; SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Ban Chang Kruea, Ban Saphan Hin); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Bang Bao), Satun (Ko Kabeng), Songkhla (Pru village); Narathiwat (Ra-ngae).
distribution: India, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Java (type), Borneo, the Philippines, Sulawesi, Lesser Sunda Islands, Moluccas, New Guinea, N Australia.
ecology: Deciduous forests, swamp forests and mainly secondary surroundings: Opened sandy soil, along path near village, deciduous dipterocarp forests around temple, bamboo thickets, edges of evergreen forests in old clearings, roadside ditches, sea level up to 600 m alt. Flowering: April, May, August, October–December; fruiting: February, October.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Songkhla (Pa Kart Non-Hunting Area, known only from one collection, Gardner & Sidisunthorn ST 2809).
distribution: Peninsular Malaysia (Perak, Selangor, Negri Sembilan, Malacca), Sumatra (Palembang).
ecology: Lowland evergreen forests.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Chawmhat, Doi Chan Pa Di, Ban Pa Deng, Doi Chiang Dao WS), Tak (Doi Musor); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Dan Sai), Nong Khai (Chaiyaburi); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Dongyai, Srisawat).
distribution: India (Sikkim, Assam (type), Manipur), Myanmar, China (Yunnan), Laos.
ecology: Grassy areas, thickets, and along small streams in primary evergreen mixed forests; shale and granite bedrock, and limestone outcrops; at 700–1,600 m alt. Flowering: May–June; fruiting: May and October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Lampang, Phrae; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Khlung, Ko Chang); SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani (Ko Tao), Phangnga (Takuapa), Trang, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Songkhla.
distribution: China (Yunnan, Hainan), Indochina, Andaman Islands, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Borneo.
ecology: In evergreen forests, ca 500 m alt. Widely cultivated for its fruits. Flowering: December–March; fruiting: February–April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang, Khao Saming), Trang, (Khao Chong), Satun (Ko Adang, Ko Tarutao, Bang Sun), Songkhla (Padang Besa, Khao Khiao).
distribution: Tenasserim, Andaman Islands, Indochina, Taiwan, throughout Malesia to New Britain, the Solomons, and Australia.
ecology: In lowland evergreen forests, on rocky ground, by stream bank, in scrub jungle along seashore, 0–300 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep), Lampang (Palat, Mae Sai Kam), Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Sakhon Nakhon (Phu Phan); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Pak Thong Chai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Si Sawat, Praten).
distribution: Myanmar, China (Yunnan), Laos, Vietnam.
ecology: Open deciduous forests, on stony ground, 50–500 m alt.

distribution: Laos, Vietnam, Cambodia, Myanmar.
